job_title: Dean of Instruction in Tacoma, WA

job_title: Instructional Program Assistant in Puyallup, WA
pros: Great coworkers and team environment among individual departments. The ground employees truly have the studen's best interest at heart and have battles with administration to do their best for the student who is the customer.
cons: Every quarter it would seem that other departments would change things up and a a clerical you MUST keep abreast of these changes. Having worked at a satellite location I was not informed of these changes in a timely manner...until I used the wrong form or process.

pros: Good pay. Opportunity to work independently with no micromanaging.
cons: Advancement depends on your willingness to participate in a “Game of Thrones” style games with upper management.

job_title: Nondestructive Testing Technician in Lakewood, WA
pros: Great people work for this organization
cons: Sometimes to much State bureaucracy

pros: Kind leadership at executive level, good work life balance, genuinely cares about student success
cons: Lack of systems, lack of training, culture of unkindness @ individual department levels

job_title: Network Operations & Security in Lakewood, WA
pros: The position I am in right now is also doubling as my internship. The instructors are great and you get out of it, what you put in.
cons: COVID has limited personal networking opportunities during this time.

pros:
CPTC is a state agency. You will get all the benefits of a state employee (sick leave, vacation leave, bereavement leave, paid holidays, retirement plans, optional disability plans, etc.) You'll have stable work hours and very rarely (most employees) will you ever have to work on weekends or past 5pm (mostly for annual events or special things you can volunteer for).  If you are a union employee, you'll have additional benefits as part of your union's collective bargaining agreement. 

Tons of opportunity for professional development and additional training (paid for as part of benefits).  You are even entitled to take one class for free a quarter at any state college/university as a benefit. So this is a great way to build on career progression. 

The campus and most buildings are aesthetically pleasing, and you will also be able to access services (oil changes, haircuts, massages, etc.) offered by the various schools. 

Most people here are super nice. It's a good place to work where people are pleasant, and generally, care about what they do/we do as a college.
cons: Select individuals who have a bad attitude, some faculty who don't care about diversity/equity, and a history of college presidents/leadership that aren't very well liked. Although, current president is kind and strives for input.

review_title: Most students here are focused and determined.
pros: As a whole, the faculty here empathetic and supportive of the students.  One of the best student environments I have ever worked in.  Great place for students who are veterans.  My dean is excellent--provides good leadership and is flexible and thoughtful.  They pay adjunct faculty well (considering the current trend).
cons: Sometimes, the way that the system is structured, students aren't held accountable or given ownership of their own student careers. I think this is mostly done because the college wants to maximize funding by mitigating the number of students that become ineligible for financial aid. Considering that this is a technical program, the college hasn't either thought about or figured out ways to for faculty/staff meetings to be inclusive.  It's at the same time every month, but many instructors teach during that time.

review_title: Tenure isn't meaningful...anyone can be RIF'ed. If enrollment dips, instructors are blamed and let go.
pros: Very dedicated support staff and faculty; though admin is often out of touch. programs are modeled after old-style apprenticeships with personal attention for each student. Great on-campus services and well maintained campus. Lots of funding devoted to beautiful buildings/facilities; although not much for employee salaries and updated equipment. Some tuition reimbursement is offered.
cons: Too little money devoted to updated technology and inadequate tech support campus wide. Faculty work load is incredibly high. Academics are very limited. Certain people are favored w higher pay and opportunities, while others are pigeonholed. Very behind with technology; resistant to online offerings and new educational models. Much of curriculum hasn't changed in many years...Enrollment numbers drive everything. Keeping students in seats is valued over quality and excellence. weak Faculty union.

pros:
Able to help mostly non-traditional college students reach career training goals for IN DEMAND careers. 
Excellent location for bus commuters from many different places.
cons: Slow progress in changes to expand the college and services provided for better growth of the college. Programs don't accept enough students to allow more people access to this type of education.

pros: Laid back job. Everyone is very nice and easy to work with.Flexible hours most of the time. Minimal supervision.
cons: Other than it being an on call position;I cant find a con unless your just a naturally like to complain.

review_title: A warm caring place where employees are dedicated to the mission of the college
pros: Feels like a family, mission is worthy
cons: Part of state governmental bureaucracy

pros: Feels great to work in a place focused on learning
